zZhBiivvN4Iq-hyzS9XvMQ.review_text: Johnny Nitro featuring the lady sax player whose signature move is to walk around on top of the bar during her "Mercury Blues" solo and then... jump off!!!!  This is a classy town.

u7_qkKX5nOm6y5wc5pbmwg.review_text: Go on a Thursday night, when they have a live blues band.  It's an older crowd (30's, even 40's), but a great little place to get your swing on with a date or your bf/gf... no matter how old you are.  Don't be intimidated by the beer wench behind the bar.  She may throw your change at you, no joke, but not to worry... at least you're getting a $2 cold beer.   I went here on my first date with my man (his recommendation) and it was a hit!  I love this bar.

17dx_x9W_7QBT-3oiQQEQQ.review_text: I'm the kind of girl who orders whiskey neat.  This whiskey neat is more of a pint of whiskey neat.  Holy shit.  Most phenomenal blues any night of the week.  I love the patrons here- they break up the monotony and drone of all other bars/clubs in town.

LAYE5MppHHXyGcBSDogsUw.review_text: Good Blues- check! old school down to earth bartenders- check! dancing to live music- check! good liquor(even the box wine seems ok:)- check! This place has been around since 1861 and it seems nothing much has changed about it! I love SF! I love The Saloon!!!!!

GJsRGdnvfGsG3w0becDD2w.review_text: One of my favorite dives in the city. Cash only, limited beer selection and kinda stinky inside but the music and dancing can not be beat!!!

r4ZXc4HYIiTyTp2E6BV7WA.review_text: Old wood, old glass, old regulars and some new youngins from all over the world. I had two of the weirdest bar experiences of my life here. Only enhanced by the atmosphere.    1) Bloody Marys at nearly 10:30 in the morning with people I had just met in a hostel and joke-telling barflies looking well over 70. "Do you want to hear a joke? This one is just for the ladies. A man walks into a brain store to buy a brain. There are two brains in jars on the shelf. The brain on the left is half the price of the brain on the right. The man asks why. The store clerk replies "Because its been used." Ba-bum-ching!  &  2) A Jazz/Blues band at night with an Australian student, a French teacher from France and a ridiculous aspiring political consultant from Arizona.   All pours were *generous* pours, maybe not the delicate kind of mixology you would get in NY but Sweet  Jesus was there vodka in there.   This bar will always hold a special place in my heart. I searched for 'dive bar' on yelp and the best kind of 'dive bar' Yelp and San Francisco did provide. Your beer options will be limited. PBR will be the only thing on tap and cash only. BUT, you *will* walk out with stories.

tRaVOHBS9l_6hdwSQ0Q5Kg.review_text: I love you Saloon!!  Thank you for your excellent music and total unpretentious-ness.  Yes I made up that word.  If you are kick back and like to have a good time then drop by.  Music is great and people are always friendly.  See you there!

9DVpnoTOOMaDfLCKppI9pA.review_text: Cheap cover (when they charge it) - cheap drinks and always a great band.  This place is so much fun and probably the most inexpensive date in North Beach.  Always crowded for a reason and it's great watching the tourists stare=ing gape jawed when the musicians walk across the bar.  Ignore the kids like Alexa, they want video games and TV monitors, this is what a real saloon looks, smells and sounds like.

F01s5dK-Rit8g_SlSkJdTA.review_text: The first time I came to The Saloon, it was on a date with this guy. It didn't end up working out for us, but I heard later that he used the same three step process for all of his dates. Meet a girl at a classy wine bar in North Beach. Take her across the street to Firenze by Night (where he is conveniently friends with the owners) for dinner, and then take her to The Saloon for some blues music, where he can show off his fabulous dancing skills. Hey, I can't knock his method. It worked on me!  Anyway, I love The Saloon for numerous reasons. The bartenders are totally crabby, but once you're in, you're in. They bring in the most awesome blues bands, and everybody, I mean EVERYBODY, will want to get down and boogie.   Whenever I feel like dancing the blues away, literally, I'll come to The Saloon. It beats any of those crap ass North Beach dance clubs any day.

_zwYMD_flEZ3AJPjrXYc4w.review_text: As I read posts here, I think that one of the biggest issues is expectations.  If you expect to be treated like the King or Queen you think you really are.. by all means go elsewhere.   If you expect to impress a date, you best be over 50 and she best be from New Orleans... If a fine afternoon every once in a while, is sitting back, listening to Etta James or Howling Wolf while chatting with strangers, then any afternoon would be good.  If you don't mind dancing with women who want to dance to the music, rather than trying to impress you with their moves is fun, this place is for you.  For what it is this place is the best, in the City, in the State, and is comparable with  the best blues bars in the South.  We are damned luck to have this place and it deserves our appreciation, and it deserves our respect.  My thanks to Myron Mu for keeping this tradition alive.

Lb37hatAjI3fgHEh2lMNEw.review_text: It always seems bad from the outside. The Saloon has the smell of 100+ years of dried up beer and vomit. The barkeep is kind of mean. The bathroom needs to be buried underground for 200 years before it should be used by any man or woman.  But hey, it's not all bad. The blues are amazing and well worth the cover. My recommendation is to get sloshed for $2 a pint at king of thai noodle house next door first, then come over here and you'll be drunk enough not to notice the smell or want another drink. If you need to pee.. go back to KoTN... please.  P.S. Watch out for the cougars. My friend damn near hooked up with one of them.

-aUOAVRvdLnryQLI4tY8LQ.review_text: This place is the oldest bsr inn San Francisco and one of the oldest bars in the US. It survived earthquakes, fires and the Prohibition and it definitely looks and acts the part.   The bar, with the wooden panels and mirrors, makes me think of Al Capone time, as if you stepped through a time machine door and are now in the 20s. When you walk inside, it has that 'bar' reek, and to me that's just another sign of authenticity. The staff is laid back (gotta love their 'bouncer'), and the crowd is cool. Nothing pretentious, everyone is just having a great time. The music will make even the squarest of squares get on the dance floor and shake that flat booty of theirs. And the drinks? Stiff, overflowing, and cheap. This is one hell of a place!

s5XJsJNNI944pvNKsb_OeA.review_text: The oldest bar in San Francisco. We had to see it. It looks like the oldest bar in the city. Might even be the original paint and floor coverings. There was live, wild Blues happening when we walked in. Lots of local customers; we stood out as tourists. We visited a few minutes but left. Not our kind of place.

1D5EQITb4hOzPMZT8gDPQQ.review_text: I was dragged here the other night by some friends who were meeting people at The Saloon. My first impression... gross. The place was full of old people dressed in leather and smelled as old as it claims to be. Honestly the place just kind of left a bad taste in my mouth.  That being said, one star for the jazz band playing in the back and one for being the oldest bar in SF.

nYufXwZH9ooB_zjNJf8Xlg.review_text: Never had a bad time here..more of a stop as opposed to a destination, don't set your expectations too high and you'll have a good time. I'm not a big fan of live music, but I find the bands here to be kind of funky and worth checking out especially since they aren't too loud usually. FYI-it's pretty divey and I don't even think they have a TV so keep that in mind as well.,,

cU1n3tkLPW67R8gcfyQtrA.review_text: For me there is a very good reason to come here on a Saturday night. Ron Hacker, the 65 year old blues guitarist with his band .He plays here once or sometimes twice a month and for $5 you can see and hear this genius. He does a couple of sets starting at 9.30 pm and at the end of each set you can buy a c/d or book by him or even a t-shirt , if you ask politely he will sign your souvenir. The grisseld  barmen pour a quality drink and are more than fair to one and all. Check the calender and visit this bar and hear Ron Hacker. It is a privilege. sfblues.net/Saloon/Saloo…

BGdFcjoXSDfVRWMgaOOgaw.review_text: awesome music, great atmosphere, real people, and it scares away tourists. FUCKING AWESOME BAR.

G3QxRKxd0AdzcHyXjPETEA.review_text: I have a love/hate relationship with The Saloon, but mostly I love it.    The love part comes from the live music, and the hilarious people who dance around in front of the stage and don't give a shit whether they look cool or not.  They're just having a good time, and that's exactly what I can't get enough of!    The hate part comes from the long narrow bar area... if you get squeezed in against the wall in that area then it just sucks because you are constantly being pushed up farther against the wall by people coming in and out.. but whatev, it happens.  Also, if you enjoy getting hit on by much, much older people, then this is your spot!  But don't worry, it's all in good fun.  Everytime I come here, without fail, someone in my group gets hit on by someone who is old enough to be our parent.    Bottom line is that The Saloon has lots of character.  The drinks are cheap, the music is fun, and the crowd is eclectic.  I've heard something about it being the oldest bar in San Francisco.. and it definitely looks like it.. in a very good way.

3Ttx_EwurF4tVRn723SIjw.review_text: I feel a little bad about writing this review because  I've only been here once and it was with a co-worker, it was almost 3 years ago when I worked in the financial district and felt the need to drink heavily and often, and I was so completely hammered when I finally made it here that all I hardly remember being there at all.    But with all that said, I do have a general memory of having a damn good time.  This is my kind of dive--  small, non-touristy (although the patrons are a little on the old side), limited selection of alcoholic beverages (which makes ordering easy for me), features a blues band (with some sort of obvious Southern influence), and has enough room on the dance floor to drunkenly grind with someone in a very offbeat manner, but not too much room on the dance floor where you could easily make a spectacle of yourself.

t-MrwBJmAbxHf4n3-AHO7g.review_text: This is seriously one of the best bars in the city.   It's no meat market, it's there for people who want to enjoy kick ass music in a cool atmosphere.  I have seen amazing blues, rock, and rock-a-billy-esque music there and have always had a blast.   Everyone that works there looks like they are from the gold rush (in a good way).  The place makes you want to drink whiskey all night (or their cheap busch) and take in the great tunes.    This place is like a cool test; if you like it, you are cool.  If you can't hang, I don't ever want to be your friend.  Seriously.  If you are looking to spice up your night, on a date or with a group of friends, the saloon is the place to be.  Don't forget the cash my friend!!

Rrj11KKFTDPpjhFlxU7Z6A.review_text: This bar pretty much sucks unless you are old, like bad music, like bad bartenders, and like being packed in like a sardine.  My parents love this place.

YE6MfcqTdqrqPgubWfYJ4g.review_text: Great place - one of the best blues bars in the entire country.  I got to see Danny Castro perform here when he recorded his live CD a few years ago - talk about electricity!   If you don't know who Danny Castro is, think Stevie Ray Vaughn meets Eric Clapton with Buddy Guy and Albert King thrown in for extra flavor.  He plays here once every few months and it is always packed to the rafters.  The bar guy Huck pours a mean drink and the door guy Greg makes sure that everybody plays nice.  Guys, watch your head on the way down into the bathroom, if you're over 5'4" make sure you duck.

PhD6RYScGomuiFvoKjb39g.review_text: The Saloon is a wonderful place, its my favorite bar in San Francisco. The majority of the time there is live music playing, day or night. Anywhere from blues, jazz, rockabilly, &soulful women singing. There is a mini dance floor, the drinks are decently priced. You can definitely go into this bar alone and just chill out while enjoying music; without having to worry about anyone bothering you. Its the perfect place in North Beach to escape the young yuppie crowd. You'll only encounter the elderly, or strange looking people in here & its fantastic.

mRK9h-zY6I3gGt4fxh11MQ.review_text: I love blue's bars, and I've been to them in Chicago and Los Angeles, but this one ranks up there among the best.    The drinks were stiff and the music was popping.  I didn't have a dull time here and everyone is down.  I love this place!

X-vuPnCWGMRoV3DP7cV0DA.review_text: I always enjoy exploring new places when I visit the City. We came across The Saloon yesterday and were temped to venture in because of the lively sounds of Blues music. The drinks were cheap and strong. Huck, the bartender, was amazing! I enjoyed seeing all walks of life enjoying good music. I look forward to coming back on my next visit.

5v6juPIOisfmogp7QSso-A.review_text: Dating to 1861, this is amongst the oldest drinking holes in the Bay Area. It's a mix of bikers, blues fans, and genuine characters. There is often some great live music. The bar (with PBR on tap) is cash only. The bartender is a prick. This place quickly gets crowded, so it's better to show up early.

MV7ItoAJaiDpBvdLl8dMNQ.review_text: The ultimate dive bar.  Live music.  Ridiculously cheap drinks.  The bartender and guy outside the door checkin ids both look like they've been working there for decades, and they still seem to really enjoy it.  Although, since it is a little hole in the wall and with the live music blaring, it is nearly impossible to hear the person you're talking to.  Overall, a cool place.  Drinks: 4/5 Ambiance: 5/5 Service: 3/5

VuNAe_FRVRn348KbM0Fknw.review_text: had a great time here! stayed for at least 3 sets of this amazing blues band! bartenders were on point and the dance floor was on fire! I am def coming back next time I'm in San Francisco!!

B4cJvWuf59j7XlTdexnVZw.review_text: The ultimate dive.  Old-school bar opened in 1861.  Some real history at this place you can feel in the walls.  I go by this place nearly everyday and think that they must have a special homeless person discount from the characters hanging out outside.  The place has some cheap drinks and live blues music some nights that I think might have a small cover or drink minumum some of the time.  It yuppifies on weekends, so you must go on a weeknight, to really get the true experience.

gILPvBzdDQjVGt6gIdLrew.review_text: what a place! steeped in history! an SF classic!

cNqpVwQu8bB6sqTua8Wd5w.review_text: This place was hilarious considering i looked twelve compared to everyone else. It's cool if you enjoy old school blues and are in hopes for finding some of your old high school teachers. Age range: 31 to at least 110. Yes, 110..i saw Yoda. Thank God I didn't run into my dad.  I'd definitely come here when i'm a Gilf!

9rqJpba4GRF0TZEAdqrvKg.review_text: It's truly a San Francisco institution. The place is well over 100 years old.  The bar tenders are old, the band is semi-old, furniture is old...everything is old, except the booze. Drinks are small, comparing to the standard sized drinks you can get at a regular bar, but they're cheap. Two rum and coke, with tips was $9. AND they are were not shy about giving you a bit more rum than coke. The band was great. The night I went they were playing some classic rock. People there are more of an older crowd, but friendly. Stop by when you're around north beach, the experience of bringing back the old good days is worth the trip.

W64mp57Bv35yn269fPGlCQ.review_text: Was excited...went for my birthday.  "Was" is the key component.  We got there with a group of 8 or so, at around 8pm.  Ordered a few rounds of weak drinks until 9:30 when the bouncer came by and said if we wanted to stay the cover would be $5.00 to see the band.  I did not have any cash on me at that point and my fiance` was in the restroom which I explained to the bouncer.  He came back 5 min later demanding money from us and using several curse words in the process. This was the first encounter my fiance had with the bouncer who said "what the f---- are you going to do? pay or leave?" We said we were going to finish our drink, at that point the bouncer had the bartender come over from behind the bar to let us know (my finace` and I) that he would no longer serve us until we gave him $5.00.   Mind you he had just gotten back from the restroom and he had no clue what was going on, this was his first interaction with the bouncer.  Based on principal we did not pay and reminded the bouncer that we were paying customers, with a group of 8 that had been buying drinks for several hours before the cover began.  I have never been to a bar that demands a cover from patrons inside before the posted time on the door when the cover takes effect, nor have I ever paid $5.25 for such a weak pour and lastly I have never been treated so poorly in a bar where I was gladly spending my money.  I would not have hesitated to support local talent if we hadn't been instantly treated with such hostility.

ey-4MP3wXg9byW4QFj2_dg.review_text: after partaking in a bar down the street's middle aged rock and rollers playing covers of the killers, my friends and i stumbled wearily into the saloon after a drunken woman began a conversation with us outside .  she was convincing enough for us to go in, and man, was i glad drunk lady did.    real blues with people who really dig the blues. you couldn't help but move to the music.  sooo good.  a great hole in the wall with interesting characters, fun laughter, and good music.

z9sL9d4kfAiQeGJ1dGmBng.review_text: The only beer on tap is PBR. There's live music, a funky crowd, and the floor reeks of urine. That's all you need to know.

tkubnXf8x7DkfMI6b11VMA.review_text: Total Dive Bar in North Beach. Went on St. Patricks day, Crazy!!!! This is a small bar. If you go, dont go alone, and try to go with at least a small group, may need the back up. Good luck!!!

afCyyz9-4UaT9RQqCkoCCg.review_text: Stumbled upon this gem  walking to my hostel. Great music didn't mind paying $ 5.00 cover.

bmFdLS5PddDOCsE7ICo79Q.review_text: Best bar in the city, hands down. The strangest and most fun. Only place you can dance to Johnny Nitro and The Door Slammers, BS with Greg the doorman, get served a Bud Light by the Angel of Death and smoke weed with Roy in the alley while Wille plays the harmonica - all in one night. Not to toot my own horn or anything, but they used to play Good Golly Miss Molly in my honor, even though that is not my name. GO! You get used to the smell after like a minute.

ctHYJSdfkdq_2ZrsqEFN8Q.review_text: This is one of the coolest dive bars I have ever been to. I was there on a Sunday night but they still had a decent live band. Great mix of people from young to old and the bartender was great. Oh, and the drinks are CHEAP!!! Mixed drinks were $3.50 and I got a shot of Glenlivet 12 yearr for $6.50! That is unheard of for SF, I haven't even seen those kind of prices in Baltimore. Cash only.

2HUQjb9aOyFdkJTe-yyCig.review_text: Well, I decided to quit drinking a couple of decades ago (thank God!). But on my last night out where did I want to have that last drink?  That's right, the Saloon.  Ah, the dentally challenged bartender. Loved the sign on the door saying no illegal drugs in the alley.  Loved the haggered patrons wearing original (not vintage) Jefferson Airplane t-shirts telling stories of being wasted with Carol Doda. Loved the teasing whiff of vomit coming off the patron next to you.  Loved the drunk girl crying at the end of the bar because she lost a contact lens.   Man, am I glad I quit drinking..... But this place is a great spot to have your last one!

kwLjahEd7YrUHS2c84JfAw.review_text: My favorite bar anywhere. Great blues, great crowd. RIP Johnny Nitro. "Drinking triples til we're seeing double. Feeling single, and gettin in trouble!"

0bld5wk4ezKDbM1qEM1rHg.review_text: Ended up here while waiting for our table at the Stinking Rose.   Drinks are cheap Dive Bar Sweaty Crowded   **Four stars because drinks are cheap.  Didn't really care for this place but a dive bar is a dive bar so I don't think it deserves to get any points knocked off for it.

nsawcqioX0NDmqsDsM8L4w.review_text: If you want a place that has the heart of San Francisco look no further.  This place smells as old as it is.  If you are looking to hook up this is not the place for you, unless you like older folk.  This is definitely a locals bar with a very heavy emphasis on music.  If you are in the music scene this is your kind of place especially Jazz and blues.  Andrew, a local, will greet you at the door.  Cheap strong drinks Street parking (which can be hard in N. Beach, try the public lot on Vallejo between Columbus and Stockton) Small Dance Floor Great mix of people Great music 5 Stars for the history this place has

GHQcMkEgiQesfl_2KA8LzA.review_text: Total dive with great prices on drinks.  Always good music.  Got to go if you like dives or blues or cheap drinks or loose girls. ;)

fGkpW1GpmRUQ4E3vEJTn8w.review_text: This is one of my favorite bars in San Francisco!  It's a little gem of a hole in the wall dive.  The bartenders and the regular customers are characters who all have a joke or story to tell.  The music there is usually pretty good and it's so much fun to watch people dance or to get on the dance floor yourself!

Jd1XHglA85pI3H1gXwzwfw.review_text: This place is dirty, dank and fan-frickin-tastic. The drinks take a wait, especially if it's busy, but everyone waits equally long in the end. The other bar patrons are friendly and loquacious, both with their friends, the bartender, and strangers. The night we visited the band was hoppin' there was dancing and carousing, cabs kept dropping people off at the door and still, no line and no cover. Amazing!  I overheard one of the regulars say this was the busiest they'd seen it in a while, so I can only assume the place is usually far more empty, but I've been in more crowded bars for sure. Highly recommend this joint. Super fun.

Desi-Wiz2gwPLWMXP10Bvw.review_text: The drunk bartender was making googly eyes at me as he mouthed the Billy Holiday song playing in the background and poured our drinks. Yes, we all know this is the oldest bar in SF (with Little Shamrock in the Sunset coming in 2nd) and it is a real dive - in a good way.  I was surprised to see young cute girls arriving the entire time we were there. It seems like a place for old san francisco, you know the down and out and drunk. However, Saturday night it was filled with some real cute girls and several groups of them. I think the bartender was very pleased by this. There was a rock and roll band setting up in the corner. We finished our round of (super cheap by the way) drinks and went on our way. This is a spot we always take out of town guests as it is a real glimpse into the past.

ksonr4xKjpmznXtf_rB2jg.review_text: The other roomie invited us to watch 'The Eye of Newt' perform at The Saloon last night. Her friend plays the bass in this band and they were performing because of the Blue Bear event. Of course I yelped the Saloon before heading out and read the reviews of it being the oldest bar and smelling like a urinal, but we forged ahead in support of the Newts.   All I can say is that the decor is very interesting. The woodwork was clearly from a bygone era. The bar mantle was dark, appearing smoke stained. Then you notice the faux Christmas tree changing colors from blue to red to pink. And then you see it...a little statue of Amida Buddha above the stage.   There and then you know you're in another world. You're not in San Francisco 2007. You're not even in San Francisco 1950. You're just in another world.   The staff appeared to be rejects from a biker gang complete with long hair, long ZZ-Top beards of grey, and an intoxicated swagger. Johnny Nitro from the Blue Bear School of Music also fit right in.   There was an eclectic mix of patrons that ensured you were either in another world or on acid. There were young hotties hipsters that looked barely old enough to drink. There was a late 20's preppy crowd. There was the hippie looking guy with lace up moccasin boots that didn't match the rest of his apparel. There was a gaggle of older gentlemen who appeared to be there by themselves in their late 40's. And then there were the 70+ crowd that could only have been from the neighborhood. There was a lady who pushed her way past the crowd with her 4'-0" structure but built like a sherman tank. (Literally) She looked old enough to have opened the bar. And lastly there was the guy in his 50's who stumble out of a cab, mug still full of beer, who could barely talk much less stumble in to the bar. I later saw him hitting on two of the vocalist from the Eye Of Newt. He took the rejection well.   The shots that we got were disappointing. Watching the bartender mix them, he looked like he was still tweaking. He told the drunken one that our friend, "has great bar tits" (whatever that means.) Yeah whatever dude. tittays or no tittays, It still took you 10 minutes to get our THREE beers. She might have shown them to you had you got our beers right away.   I know it is supposed to be a dive-bar but it's more like a sunk-durring-the-spanish-inquisition-by-a-cannon-­ball-and-featured-in-the-pirates-of-the-caribbean bar.  If nothing else I can say I drank once at the oldest bar in SF. If that's not enough I can say I drank in the oldest bar in SF and there were Christmas lights, a faux Christmas tree, and a buddha.   4 stars for being smart enough to have Blue Bear and the Eye of Newt perform.

0Chi_CzoTmkw1NvZg0sksg.review_text: Even before it got crowded, this place smelled like a wet homeless cat in heat.  Totally old school and unpretentious, with grey-haired bartenders serving drinks with the shakes, this place has an authenticity people are constantly looking for to exploit and reproduce into a cleaner facimilie.  Not so here, this place clings doggedly to its rugged homeliness.  It's of course cash only and cover-charge-free.  You can hear yourself some gritty blues, drink yourself some strong, cheap whisky, and meet yourself a crazy crosssection of people.

ILz8ApVEgTqbv5LnC6PyuA.review_text: Great music in an old bar with good beer, although I prefer the weekdays to the weekend here...

wRflYcdeaiXE222-hFspdA.review_text: Their claim to fame is that they're the oldest bar in San Francisco. I believe because they're one of the most divey bars in San Francisco that I've come across, which is good thing for me and if you're into dive bars. There's usually good cover band playing, so it's a good place to dance the night away for not as much money as you would pay at a club.

tVwvcuC-mIY53uT_utM_BA.review_text: This place is hilarious.  From the bartender to the people at the bar, everyone has character.  Great music and cheap drinks make me happy and that is exactly what this place has.  Come check it out!

5pp0gsA97_1AazCzmzUYQQ.review_text: Probably one of the best nights I have ever had in the city!! The husband and wife combo of bar tenders was beyond amazing!  The $5 cover was well worth it because they pour strong!! Please come out!!

iHwqxEYgwk6G3aMwGsaQGQ.review_text: This is a gritty blues bar. Stay away if you don't like the faint smell of piss and beer worn into the woodwork. The age and history of this bar is readily apparent. I always find myself slinking away from my friends to wind up here diggin blues with the old men. Quality Blues acts and the history of the place make it the best bar in SF.

DRvGPMHi1tE5gxrfiCFQww.review_text: When I thought I had already found the best jazz and blues place, I was brought to the Saloon.  On their website you can more or less find out that it is the only place in SF that survived both the earthquake and the fire -- the firemen saved the building to protect the hookers upstairs.  That may be the root of the lingering odor reported by almost everyone reviewing this place.    So with such a reputation to live up to, I go there.  Don't be afraid of the guy at the front door -- he's management.  The cool thing about this place was what I saw over the course of two consecutive nights.  On the second night, everyone that was working behind the bar was on stage, and everyone on stage was behind the bar.    Seeing the sax player come into the crowd then jump on the bar, and play while the bartender rushed to clear all the glasses as she tromped down the length of the saloon was amazing.  Either you like it or you don't.  5 Stars for me.

24yhVSA9aZ8vgEzIE_dDOw.review_text: Great place to hang out on a Sunday night. Listen to a bit of Jazz from a live band and have a few drinks. Nice atmosphere has the old dive look and feel, mainly because this is the real mcCoy! I agree with the other post of a strange smell inside, but I figure since it is the oldest bar in SF and used to be a Whorehouse as well, the whole thing add character funky smell and all. :) It is a must see.

UiX4CR188mjByb8GeI8jYQ.review_text: This is a shit hole even for a dive bar.....  Great location and I'm normally a dive bar fan but this place just blows.  We ran into some wanna be biker dudes who called themselves regulars.....  complete D-bags.  Two taps at the bar and one was kicked.  For Christ sake how hard it is to properly manage the beer inventory when you only have two stinking taps??  And what is with the geriatric bar queen dressing like she's 25?  Very disturbing!

4CPPBkXxL12I5WhzVrzdOQ.review_text: From Chicago on vacation and we wandered into this gem. Cash only but cheap and they pour em stiff. Perfect place to stop for a few beers after walking around San Francisco's steep roads. Smells likes it's SF's older bar, because it is. If you're in the area and need a relaxing stiff one, be sure to wander into The Saloon!

gjh6da4yHahEpQ73O6DX_Q.review_text: This place is legit.  From its humble beginnings in 1861, this bar has come a long way to become the oldest bar in San Fran.  It was once even a whorehouse for some time!  It probably got its name because it was THE saloon in town when it opened.  A bunch of locals, music lovers, and dive bar aficionados are the primary clientele here (although our hero hears this bar makes it into some travel guides to attract brave tourists too).  There's definitely a very aged and classic feel to this place and the bar has probably been stained with more alcohol over the past 150+ years than our hero has had in his lifetime.  The locals will pipe in with some stories as well if you ask them.  Even our hero's straight laced friend who'd never been to a dive bar before loved the bar.  Finding broken glass lying around the place on a Sunday morning from what must have been a wild Saturday night beforehand only added to the divey charm of this fine establishment.  PROS: - Historical significance of being the oldest bar in town. - Super cheap drinks.  CONS: - They only have two taps and one of them is PBR. - The beers are served in somewhat small glasses here (perhaps only 10 ounces or so)

OADwxJqXxuI30aB8HvI9QA.review_text: My boyfriend and I were out wandering North Beach for dinner and he spotted THE SALOON across the street from The Stinking Rose (where we had a great dinner).  He had heard that it was one of the best blues bar in the City.  We passed up several bright lit snobby wine bars that day in the City and landed in this oh so divey bar!  What a blast!  Eugene Huggins was playing that night.  We danced our asses off!  Awesome band.  The blind guitarist was phenomenal!  Beers were only $3.50 and no cover charge but be sure and tip the band - they deserve it!  Yes, it's what all the reviewers said before me - dingy, old, scruffy, all walks of life, but intimate, cozy, cold beer and great music.  Ultimate biker bar!

dGy6LmfgfJyftpcHVkPtEw.review_text: Man I felt like crap earlier. Just that life kinda sucks - I need to punch a hole in the wall - type of feeling. As I like my walls without holes I figured I needed something else to take my mind off of things. Booze and Blues? Damn straight.  The best thing about the Saloon is that you can just show up and relax. No primping or fancy dress code needed (not that anyone would notice with the lighting inside); which was good because I was dressed to drink.  Dave Workman (who is just incredible) was laying it down. Exactly one shot and a beer later everything worked into a nice, warm fuzz while the music took the edge off my day. I don't know why people complain about the smell in other reviews. Maybe they just aren't drinking enough? It doesn't really matter. Everything else about the bar outweighs a little odor. It can't be any worse than having some guy in a club, who bathed in Calvin Klien, standing next to you.    After another few glasses I had forgotten why I was pissed off earlier and that is why I love this dive.

Jj5tQCKCQqOTv9H_nwxJng.review_text: Man I had been wanting to go to a blues bar/lounge for the longest time.  And this place was one if a kind.  There was a cover charge to get in and they had a live band!  Once I heard the music it was non stop dancing.  The bartenders were awesome as well as the crowd.  The only thing is that the dance area was small.  The whole place was packed.  But that won't stop me from coming again.

97BHRNfBqubPqisKmj46Ww.review_text: have never had a bad time in here  an institution as the oldest during the gold rush and surviving the 1906 quake  great live music, small but cheap drinks, filmed in many movies and attracts all sorts of folks

yfG8hiLv0mA0ltTNXERuYQ.review_text: I love the live music, I love the story that it survived the earthquake, I love how it's small but there's still always some how room even when it's packed with people.  I don't love being treated like an idiot when I ask for a rum and diet coke. Is that really an unreasonable request? If all you have is regular coke then just say it, don't treat me like a jerk and ask "Why don't you just want a whiskey on the rocks, little girl?". It was almost embarrassing.  I will probably be back because overall, I like the place, but I'm never asking for anything more than a beer....and will probably make my Husband order it if that same grumpy bartender is there that obviously didn't like a younger looking woman in there.

Q2RsDOhzsCBI-F1oOPe6Lg.review_text: This place has the WOW factor not so much in a good way. It's truly a saloon. I think it's been here for about 100 years or so.   I've only been here once to judge but it only had one bartender. Plus, there is a designated area to order your drink. Oh, and you can only pay in cash. No music this day I was here, either.   The bathrooms are ancient and confusing. Kinda threw me off.   I just don't want to go to a bar with so many rules to follow. I'm trying to have a good time and not have to worry. Too many other cool places in North Beach to spend too much time here. It's conveniently located on a corner near Columbus but just keep it moving, trust me!

LinyuVqOeiK-nydF3zZrtA.review_text: Great place to hang grab a cold beer and watch some music. Great crowd , nice people.

UMD3tXY7byF8JaOmpTUoDw.review_text: Free, LIVE music that doesn't suck?! YES PLEASE! We popped in (no cover charge!!) and watched some kick ass rockabilly band playing for small but happy crowd! Cant wait to go back when we can stay longer!!

ApPUuJweItyHwmnHFQVArg.review_text: The oldest bar in SF and it is still serving up cheap drinks, clean ladies room, charismatic "regulars" and great live music.  What else can you ask for in a dive?

rde2134fSeCMWd7w0ZPctg.review_text: Damn this place is fun. A solid LIVE band, that's right real musicians, playing real music in a place that is there so you and I can enjoy some good live music, have a few drinks and have some fun.  It's an intimate place, with the front door open, people all over the place and the band shoved in the corner, cranking away on the some great blues, R&B, rocknroll, whatever...its all good.  What I think is really great about the place is that it's an honest to goodness bar that has live music nightly and does not pretend to be anything but a simple bar with good, live music.   So, you might need to duck or move out of the way quickly to avoid a brawl...Not easy to find anymore, but The Saloon has been doing it for years. Thank Goodness!

4EJCDH9ptP-js_TXY1nGyw.review_text: So the answer to your question is yes I absolutely love Jazz and The Blues.. This is the perfect place to be, outgoing friendly people, warm setting, casual flirty dressy place. A lot of regulars, and new people searching for a place where they could take it easy going and still have a good time!  I guess you'd obviously have to be very open minded to end up here. The setting is very old fashioned, bring cash!

1I1Zr6yuTkyPRiqe8qD5Ow.review_text: The saloon gets five stars because it's a SF institution. It's SF's oldest bar, been in the same spot for 150 years. It's got a beautiful old wooden bar, good drinks and prices, a great older crowd and great live music, what else can you ask for. It's not a huge place so it can get pretty crowded, so be prepared.

QwMbQmeywX9cAb60T9TG5w.review_text: Total Dive bar in every sense of the word. But great music and a really great crowd. The restrooms were even cleaner than I expected. My husband and I had come here during our anniversary weekend and had a blast. We'll be back for sure.

Z-5WllyN_Pb8CrYNR0gZyg.review_text: Very cool little bar that has cold PBR on tap. Make sure to come when a band is playing. It's a lot more fun.

VEgMc0Jat_HMTrnQ3ZWnEw.review_text: Cash only.  Was in SF for the weekend and my bf and I met some of his friends here.  I agree with others the music is so loud that you cannot hear the person next to you which can be a good thing from time to time.  I really enjoyed kicking back with a beer and listening to the awesome live band.  This place oozes history.  Definitely a place I would like to visit again.

ODSH1it5oAUPu2clIgOvyg.review_text: Awesome little place with live music. We got here just in time for last call and a few last songs. The crowd here is older, but definitely a fun crowd, including the bartender who was having more fun than I was! Cool place to come hang, watch a live music performance, and do a little dancing.

eurIEcpGa_tTi1LMWa1pUA.review_text: Nice crowd, if not a bit funky at times ... Decent selection of brew on tap and good staff. My date wanted hot tea and he gave it to her for free. You earned a big tip, my friend.   The place oozes history (which is a clever way to say that it smells funky sometimes), and it was featured in a movie with Reese Witherspoon! Could you ask for more?

wVpwTZ0ynSgHWn_tgzx2vg.review_text: Alright scratch that.  After living around the corner from the Saloon for months now, I am totally OVER the hoards of drunk people pissing and shitting and puking and doing god knows what else all over this corner.  I get it, ok?  "It's funky, it's a landmark, it's old school"  IT'S NASTY.  I'm sick and tired of stepping over all the drunk people passed out in the ally outside of this place.  Oh I'm sorry to wake you from your beauty sleep, Mr. Passed-Out, Strung-Out Saloon Patron, but you seem to be face down in the blacktop.  JEESH. ******* I live around the corner from The Saloon, and I'm always amazed at the amount of drunk people outside at any time of the day, seven days a week.  Great music, affordable drinks, and definitely not your everyday crowd of bar patrons.  There's surprisingly a lot of space inside too.  Definitely a funky place.  I lived in New Orleans for 4 years and The Saloon definitely has a Big Easy feel.

fYX66QrOI6OGTWaUhNkprQ.review_text: i was told that this place is the oldest bar in the city and back in the day there was a brothel upstairs. i thought cool. old dive bar filled with the ghosts and whores of Charles Bukowskis'. i just had to check it out. especially, since i'm a fan of dive bars. so i dragged along my sister and friend.  as i walked up to the door, the ghost of some old gold miner sat quietly at his post. he didn't say much to me, nodded his head and signaled me to go in like i was some child being lured into the greatest place in the world. he smiled behind his large beard and didn't charge me the $5 cover posted on the door. when i turned around he was gone.  i didn't make it too far in. I didn't get eaten by wolves, or take a bite of that delicious red apple. i made it as far up to the bar and that's when i saw my sister holding up a scarf to her face. yep she was gagging and so was the girl who came in after us. now me, i was taking it in like most do dive bars, but the sister and friend wanted out. pronto. and out we went.   dark bar. yes. cheap drinks. i'm sure. good music? i imagine so. but man, this place smells like straight up funk. piss, sweat, tears and blood collected throughout the years. my sister and friend will never come back here. as for me, maybe. i think after a certain amount of time you kinda get used to the smell. i wouldn't dare use the restroom though. maybe i'll come back when i am pretty drunk already and the smell doesn't bother me a whole lot.  it is a neat looking bar. i just wish it didn't smell THIS bad.

aNKbZV7sTLqeZau7hf7fJQ.review_text: my favorite dive in the city, and it has the best consistent (and nightly) blues in the country, IMHO.  re: the smell...i believe that 10% of all women who enter have a gene that triggers an I-can't-stand-the-smell-of-this-place reaction. it's funny to watch them: they walk in, crinkle their face, hold their nose, and walk out.  oh yeah, don't forget to check out the Reese Witherspoon autograph in the men's room.

tmxIsLKcNd9qG6nbL6ONbg.review_text: Live music, slightly order crowd. Ended up with a pabst because it was the only beer on draft. But you're not coming here fir the drinks.

TS2j_gt5qugbmQ1R_fq6TA.review_text: I have tried to give this place a chance on two occasions. Actually, I even made it to their bathroom which makes the bathrooms on a 737 seem spacious. The second time, the smell from the multiple borderline homeless customers was too much for us to take, so we were on our way....

BwTPj8XS_iqdSTLPBVMs1w.review_text: Was it me? or did it smell like tinkle as you walk in here?  Bleh, who cares. I love my bars that way...nice and wet. The bartender here was this older lady. She explained why the drinks were cheap (CASH only) and that they get more expensive after 9:30pm. Fine with me since it was only 9pm. Had a beer, listened to some band tune their music and left. Great hole in the wall once you get passed the smell.

gsWHMddVl6HrF5QPmBkprw.review_text: Outstanding dive bar!  It's cash only so come well provisioned.  Blues beer & scotch (though not a wide selection of scotch) & dancing to live bands .  Friendly bar tender.

VvMDnYfkfwyLXfl_ei37Vg.review_text: a little hole in the wall right in heart of North Beach! quaint bar with live blues music and people cutting a rug all over the place! it is definitely one of San Francisco's landmarks! if its fun times your looking for, this is the spot! don't go here if you have somewhere to be after wards. You'll want to hang out here all night!!!

umte1cjoM-Bnh2gOR3GQCg.review_text: I continue to hear amazing things about the saloon, and I continue to sweet talk my way past the bouncer to see what all of the fuss is about, but I have yet to last more than 10 minutes in here. For as much dive bar charm as it has, and as great as the music is, I CANNOT get  past the smell!! I don't consider myself sensitive when it comes to bad smells, but this place has such a high temperature from all the dancing people crammed into a small space that I feel like I can literally see the smell rising off of peoples backs. I'll probably keep going to see what everyone else raves about, but so far, 3 stars.

XUm4bJy5seRuG_OELvRGGQ.review_text: Hey if you don't "GET" this place.  You just ain't cool.

cMoQqT_j_FD1gO6EEZzOIg.review_text: Does being the oldest bar in town mean you have to have geriatric employees who behave like bitter grandparents who never hear from their family?  What a major disappointment.   I figured I'd make this my last stop on my bar crawl but the experience was too bad I needed to get that awful taste out of my mouth. (That awful taste was a warm Budweiser)   I got here at 1 o'clock, band was playing, good number of people and seemed like a good vibe.   I approached the bar to order drinks. The lady behind the bar wasn't the kindest of people. I ordered some beers and she informed me they didn't have anymore of what I wanted. I then asked what they did have. She gives me this death look and then makes a gesture that I should look around. Seeing how I did that and that the tap I wanted was kicked, I wanted to know what else I had before I asked again. After discussing it with my friend, I ordered some Stellas. She then informed me that had no more Stella. Typical. Then I asked again, what they did have? She tried mumbling something. I told her to just let me get some Budweisers. She poured our drinks and made some comment that I should smile more. I smile, plenty lady.  Right after getting our drinks the band wraps up. That's cool. Then the lights come on. That's fine. It's still 1:20. Then this guy comes. The old guy who is cleaning up the bar is just harassing people. And what may not have been but felt like it, especially me. Listen dude, it's 1:20. If I want, I can guzzle four beers in forty minutes. Don't rush me for my one beer. It's still early. This guy was relentless. Trying to talk to my friends was impossible, with how often he would come over. It wasn't even 1:30 and this dude is up our behinds.   In the end, we finished our beers in no time and left. Hope harassing us to make sure you left maybe 5 minutes earlier was worth losing business.   Never come here.

wQ9t5kwmgT0ZER7P5_yKxA.review_text: favorite bar in san francisco. hands down. the bands are always incredible. the drinks are the cheapest and stiffest in san francisco. the bartenders are helpful and hilarious. this place has been open since 1861 (longer than any bar in sf) and was saved during the fires because of the well known prostitutes living upstairs.   go to this bar and pretend it's 1861.

V-rbYViHmecQGapze7bQYg.review_text: despite all the negative comments by those agist, sexist, elitist shallow minded folks, the Saloon is the oldest operating bar in SF and is also the home of the blues 365 days a year. thank your lucky stars that it exists!

r_bKgZFD761MvvZcN6qkKA.review_text: SF institution. Amazing music. But here's a tip, bartenders are usually wasted by 8, and feel entitled to ignore you for whatever their drunken reason. Come buzzed, enjoy the tunes, walk a block away for drinks and service, and come back and tip the bands. Sounds lame, but service is everything. Not that it matters here.  Awesome music though. Bring a flask.

4LMErvQTSEx6pXVAXAJaQw.review_text: This is a taste of the "old" San Francisco.  You know, back in the day when my forebears would have gotten their asses beat if they wandered out of Chinatown in and into North Beach.  Not like today's North Beach with non-Italian Italian restaurants and Chinese businesses deep into North Beach.  Still, I don't appreciate paying a $5 cover for a band that didn't play.  As I walked in, I was assaulted by a sight and a smell.  The sight, an old man passed out sitting on a barstool in a corner.  My liver felt sympathy pains for his cirrhosis.  The smell was like the smell of a urinal, not quite piss, but there was a smell of chemicals (like urine cakes) trying to clean and or mask the smell.  But the drinks are insanely cheap for San Francisco, and it was a delight to see cracked out bartenders pour more whisky on to the bar than into my glass.  Yes, this is authentic, old-school San Francisco.  But sometimes the past should just remain in the past.

F9tOE0d09SLkCIZwt8I-0g.review_text: Yeah, sure, it's a dive bar, but I've been in better dive bars.  First, it smelled like they hadn't cleaned the place since 1864, and some of the furniture looked downright scary. We didn't dare venture into the restrooms, and left after one drink.  What's disappointing is that here's a place that's "the oldest bar in San Francisco", and that alone could bring in more traffic if they fixed up the place -- and I'm not talking a major fix up, just applied some elbow grease.  But it is a drinkin' bar, so if you are looking for a place with cheap drinks and want to drink with the locals, this is it.

Zcr90BeQ8QWV32XIqpH82A.review_text: What a great, great dive bar.  Honestly.  They dont' come much better.   I can't believe I have not reviewed this place yet.   My friend Tom, who loves all things divey, swears that this is the best bar in the City.  I might not go that far, but this is a gem.   I was most recently here after the North Beach festival and they had a killer band, Second Hand Smoke, playing.  We danced the entire time.  And I think I have maybe danced 12-14 times in my life.  I hate dancing.  When I do, I usually feel like a monkey dressed in women's clothes (I'm a male monkey) standing on a barrel and doing a gig for the amusement of drunk sailors.  Seriously.  I felt like this at my wedding.  But at the saloon, man, it felt great.   That's a good bar.

5Xp1puM4TMVPvwox_ryu6A.review_text: Hey, at least it doesn't smell like barf, the way the Irish bars out in the Avenues do! What's a little piss among friends?  This is where to loosen your tie and/or corsets and just have a good ol time.  Enjoy!

Ht6UsXDORUmtMNcDqosaPQ.review_text: As an Ohioan I appreciate Dave Workman playing at the Saloon twice a month.  SF is lucky.  Saloon reminds me of Dick's Den in Columbus, OH.  Dirt cheap drinks and as many characters as you can fit in a bar.  I hope this place never closes and stays the same.

-ZNZxzThcTlJfDFWPWIX3w.review_text: The Saloon, arguably the best bar in San Francisco, maybe in all of the Western Hemisphere.  The neon lights and smell of delicious beverages captivates passers-by on a nightly basis.  The 1 drink minimum ensures that the riffraff stay away, the drinks are priced right, and the vibe is so alluring.  All in all, the Saloon makes House Party look like House Party 2.

Jj-G6cxvYGcoffIKsfWGuA.review_text: A really fun place to go and a must-see if you are visiting from out-of-state. I hear it's very historical. Bring cash they do not accept credit cars.   Oldest bar in San Francisco.

sRQu5rrkNXe5yXjKvPqWrQ.review_text: Dark and dingy, with cheap drinks, and great live music.  This place is chock full of friendly regulars and the bartenders are really nice. There beer list is pedestrian but the ambiance is really worth a PBR.

V8j4lrXSzSt_F29zhhGQ8w.review_text: The Saloon is one of the last authentic bars where you can dance, drink and see the best in Bay Area blues.  The musicians are all pros and give a great show full of flavor and down-home humor.   If you're looking for a squeaky clean gentrified restaurant/bar were you can chit chat over fancy drinks and nachos, then stay in the burbs!

7EzKV5tGQFOuuJCx4rbDHw.review_text: The place is a true dive, the bartenders seem to be always altered, but it is fantastic.  The music is always good, the regulars look out for each other and as long as you go with the flow, you will have a wonderful time.  A true gem in San Fran...uptight people need not apply.

pgHCj7DSqI8NWx7WucnH3w.review_text: I've lived in North Beach for 5 years and finally getting around to writing a review on The Saloon? Shame on me.  The Saloon is a staple in SF, the oldest bar around, and worth going just for its history, but its more than that. They also legitimately host some of the best live Blues music you'll find in the Bay. And its all free.  Yeah, you're not gonna be treated like you're a unique and valued customer. And no, you're not gonna love going to the bathroom. But you know what you're signing up for. And thats a no-nonsense, authentic fun time at a kickin bar thats about havin a good time and couldn't care less about what you think of it.

XJgRdHOsgypEba4oKwAh1w.review_text: This place is not for everyone--it's a dive bar in every sense of the word--but it's a great place for people so inclined.  The blue music is great, the bartenders are attentive, the crowd is incredibly diverse and interesting--what's not to love?    Of course, if you like your bars and bathrooms clean, this might not be the best place for you.  But if you're into good music, cheap drinks, and people watching, this is the place!

P7QJ1nKAdc3bWGq9GBjmZQ.review_text: Down and dirty bar. Great place to sit in the shadows and listen to some good music. Make sure you got cash on hand.

y3HFVx8nbNmomSc-PWOy-g.review_text: After so many years, I can't believe that I have never reviewed this place before.  The oldest bar in San Francisco, there is a ton of history here.  As such, it is also the last of the real bars.  Everything in this bar, including patrons, is real.  Not for everyone...there is nothing trendy about this place...no poseurs, no see and be seen.  This is an old school drinking establishment with strong drinks and live bands where you go to hang out and drink.  The bartenders have all been there a long time and are always wonderful to me.  Prices are great too, especially in the daytime.    The place has a divey, but fun vive and people are friendly in here...this is not one of those "let's dress up and go there as a group to look cool before we go home again as a group" kind of places.  Not by a long shot.  If Mickey Rourke's character from the film Barfly was drinking in the neighborhood, this place would be his bar of choice.  All my biker friends hang out here too which makes it even more fun and interesting.   The Saloon is definitely one of my must stops whenever I'm drinking in North Beach and when barhopping the other night after a UYE (Unofficial Yelp Event...thanks Maureen!), this was my first stop of many that evening.  You get a little bit of everything in here...good times!

xa9wLlbp5U_jXK7xcu_HGg.review_text: Worth a stop for a drink, as it's one of the oldest bars in the US. Interesting decor, dust all over the place, but it's kind of neat. Hopefully you can make it in when there's a band playing. Very dive.  The bartender at the time when I went was nice as pie.  My only personal gripe was that there's only one tap line. But they have a decent selection of liquors and bottled beers.

UCTin7iQ_oR0E11EYemsEw.review_text: Not for the faint of heart. A San Francisco staple that stays original.   Bring friends who like blues and grungy places. Avoid it if you're looking for something clean, trendy, or uplifting.

Dry25R78VCRZgn6se-q6_w.review_text: My boyfriend and I visited The Saloon on our trip to SF in 2012 and had the most amazing time!  Great dive bar with awesome music.  We met a man outside just outside The Saloon, and it appeared as though he might have been living on the streets of SF.  His name was Osiris.  If anyone knows anything about him, please let us know.  We had a spiritual encounter with Osiris, and think about him often.  We call him an angel.   My e-mail is mtkillion@gmail.com

rXops73qsJgW91oImt7UJA.review_text: From the outside this spot has a total biker bar look to it, but once you get in you realize that it is more of a 55 year olds getting drunk and dancing sort of spot.  This fabled watering hole is one of the oldest in the City, and didn't burn down during the fire/earthquake of 1906 because the firemen wanted to save what was at the time also one of the City's favorite whorehouses.    Although the whores are gone, the bar is still here serving $3 well drinks and having live, mostly blues, music every night.  Make sure to check out the stained glass windows near the front.  Last night the bartender carded my friends and after they explained that they were carded at the door, the barkeep answered, "By who?  That guy doesn't work here."  So what if the crowd is old, smells a little, and is usually shit-faced drunk, the Saloon might just be the bar that all other dive bars are trying to emulate.

sSFgjECKS4NIw-e_Vx9UuA.review_text: After starting at Gino and Carlo we arrived at the Saloon to catch the end of a jamming group playing some fine blues.  We were early (sun hadn't yet set) but it was still quite busy.  The door guy was very helpful and friendly, the drinks cheap, but the bar tender got pretty occupied.  This, the oldest SF bar, is a must on any North Beach tour.

xupIYrEgJHC7hkEx8KDQCw.review_text: Unpretentious. Unapologetic. Straight-up bar, saloon, honky-tonk dive; call it what you will. What it reeks of is authenticity. Anyone reviewing this place who gives it five stars is a good person to go out on the town with. IMHO.

E6RTdVTqzim2wOviazV3TQ.review_text: wow, this is a rough place.  all the crazy old men that crowd cafe trieste in the mornings begin and end their nights here :)  Sometimes I'm not sure if its a homeless guy or the doorman asking me for my ID.  All that being said, you can't beat the people watching here -some great characters stumble in and out of this place at all hours of the day/night.  Drinks are cheap, the entertainment (besides the patrons) has been decent so far! I like to end my evenings here.

dim5Svrt-B1jvvQsOIX22A.review_text: I've been here a few times, and this is definitely my idea of a rowdy Saturday night.  Cheap drinks and great live music.  The crowd tends to be older men who drool over anything in a skirt or cleavage.  The last time we were there, an older gent offered me and my friend drinks as soon as we walked in the joint.  He then told me his kids (who are my age) would kill me if they saw it happening.  Popular place so you might have to wait a few minutes for your drink.  I think it attracts a lot of Bridge and Tunnel people on the weekends so don't say that you weren't warned!

k1pDGshQONPqmEwQLOkD8A.review_text: Legit.  Fun.  Historic.  If you are making the rounds of North Beach bars, this is a must visit.  PBR on tap (usually).  Great music.  Greatest customers.  Dance floor.

MjCIBCRp7p4B_ITMWDpKzQ.review_text: This bar is typically not my scene, but on a random night with a lot of friends, I was able to really enjoy myself here. We ended up here after the Mojito bouncer yelled at us for blocking "his" sidewalk. So we left and kind of just wound up here. It's apparently the oldest bar in the city, and the inside didn't smell very wonderful at all. However, the door guy was really chill, and let my girlfriends and I in for free (there's usually a $5 cover). Live jazz & blues, lot's of dancing, and the crowd is definitely on the older end. I think I saw at least 5 Santa look-a-likes inside. I don't think I'd ever hit up this place purposely, but I can imagine I'll end up here again.  FYI... it's cash only

dfYNTBw--CYlZbFz581kYQ.review_text: Apparently the Saloon is the oldest or one of the oldest bars in SF... I can't confirm or deny this but it definitely is divey. There is a little stage for live music and I often walk by and hear the live music a-playing. I've only been in this bar two or three times even though it's in my neighborhood. The drinks are fairly cheap but there aren't that many choices for what specific type of rum, vodka, or mixer you'd like. There are definitely no fancy SF specialty drinks here either. I'd usually rather head to other spots on Grant such as Tope (they have specialty drinks that are much better), Tupelo (live bands that I know and TV's watching sports games), or Church Key (specialty beer bar). I won't say no if a friend really wants to hit up the Saloon though.

cbPlBWeXVGwy5Kb-LQ9lmQ.review_text: MY FAVORITE BAR!  This place has to be the best bar I've ever been to: - Cheap drinks ($3.50) - Great Blues Music (older and new) - Dancing (various ages from 20s to 50s)  Why try any where else, when you know you'll end up here. Every time I go it's a fun night.  QUICK TIP: When the band takes a break, head outside for some more live music happening in the alley from more musicians.

U-Stpt0SX7OWFYfpAL532w.review_text: Hi ho, Bridge and Tunnel here... but had an SF guide - so thankfully we didn't make TOO much of an arse of ourselves on St Patricks Day.  Live music was cool; bawdy old rock and rollers/bluesmen that they were, but loud as f.  Saloon gets an extra star for letting our drunken-by-3pm, green-clad asses in the door when no one else would.  And an extra star cause the bar keeps didn't look like tranny hookers.  This was the bar that I met this adorable Englishman, and the one my friend was fed a continuous line of small(um think juice glass when you were eight at grandmas), but apparently quite stong vodka tonics by some dorks apparently from IOWA.  WTF?  Baking power?   Then she puked in the bathroom hallway at Figaro's and I stepped in it.  When I found out it was hers (apparently I was being fed a stream of Coronas and didn't  notice the way her face now matched her St Pat's fare) and cleaned her shirt off for her.  Aren't I a nice friend?

PrqhlhGVjq5FuaM9pW6Enw.review_text: Even tho the bartender and patrons looked like extras from the movie "The Hills Have Eyes" - I loved it here.  We aren't from these parts and had a tough time finding out where to go where we could: A)  Avoid a cover charge B) Get strong libations C) Not mortgage our home for said libations D( w/in walking distance of Broadway (checking out some strip clubs for next time)  This is the place.  Don't judge the people who are drinking and enjoy your hella cheap, hella strong cocktail.  The bartender looked like a "rode hard and put away wet" Bettie Page.  I'm not complaining - cuz she'd probably kick my ass.  Besides, she made some pit bull mean long islands - NIIICE!  Oh yeah - there was a band playing some Rick Springfield music (or something) in any event - they were enjoyed as well!  We WILL be back.  ALOT.  GUARANTEED.

gxoxI92jcOScCT5-Cx702Q.review_text: Bad ass bar tender who looks like she could whip you up a great plate of pasta and kick your ass all at the same time.  good live blues music to dance to as soon as you've drank enough. its a bit older crowd, but a refreshing break from the scenesters.

t-YxjWiEuJIHRk0XAH4YkA.review_text: i lived above this place for 6 months when i just moved here and.... just wait... the entertainment in the alley outside rivals that music.  i mean i love The Blues and all that but....  c'mon super wasted crack-heads arguing is a close second..   well.. only now that i don't have to hear it everyday.  5 STARS!!!!!!   Dave Workman plays every other Sat in the afternoons.... that the guy to see! trust me, i've heard 'em all.

Fe7ikq0jVy3P4vtu3PQTCw.review_text: Warning:  Old white men will try to solicit young females to dance.    Went to this place because the ol music teacher made me review a live band.  Some how, I ended up here.  As the "bouncer" was giving me change, this old couple decides to shove me out of the way.  Jerks!  My friends and I akwardly stand about and attempt to order a drink.  The woman bartender notices that I have tits and decides to ignore me.  Then a man who appeared to be the "bar back" made my screwdriver, which was really strong by the way.  No complaints regarding the drinks, but the atmosphere was unwelcoming.  They either didn't like a younger crowd...or a younger minority crowd.  I would never go back!

yu-W5WPtzdpsDAfiewAe3A.review_text: Now this is a bar!    I will continue to elaboarate on my specific experience in just a moment here, but I have to say - I I think this may be my personal version of  heaven.  Not one young attractive man has ever tried to pick me up, the wine is stanky and 3 dollars and I can dance to my crazy hearts content with no fear of realistic booty bumping.  For those of you who know me, you probably also know I'm destined to become your witchy, cat-lovin, music playin, dancin in the garden sort of neighbor that avoids normalacy like the plague.  I'm not so bad yet, but believe me - when a 60 year old man jumps off the bar and lands on his knees while my friend and I are serenaded by 3 white haired saxaphone cooters rolling around on the ground like siezing slugs - I wish I wish I wish I stay there forever.

UXgvagwYM0gr4MRvpgeGOw.review_text: I went there a few month ago, Curtis Lawson was playing. I don't know much about blues but I loved it. I liked the atmosphere which was very open, just having beers, enjoying very good music, no show off! Really relax! That's where I started enjoying San Francisco!

HPa7MNIwUyV5QBHVMMXujg.review_text: Hey Alexa...stay away...Zeitgiest has a spot for you and your skinny jeaned boyfriends..  With that said, The Saloon is a great little spot to hit ANY night of the week and find a really cool, dark little watering hole with a live band. The bar itself usually has a door guy checking ID's...go inside and find a bar, a small dance floor and an area for the band....  Its dark, pours a good drink, has a bathroom (which like all in SF are small dirty and full of grafiti...in other words perfect)....there is dancing, live music and a very diverse cool crowd....Im a fan

CQ5h932tp5HoBaEho9L24g.review_text: This is my favorite San Francisco bar by along shot. If you're a yuppy or want to meet cuties this is not your kind of place but for jazz or blues with a great vibe it's the best.

9y3amkDxxqvk9oReRmfp-w.review_text: Much has been said about the oldest bar in San Francisco. Yes, it's old, yes, it is a dive, and yes, you can have one of the greatest experiences there. There is a doorman that takes your money at the door, a crusty old biker looking dude, but he doesn't discriminate whether your're young or old, rich or poor, the only criteria as far as I can tell, is you need to get ready to have some fun. It's not uncommon to see people there dressed to the nines, shaking and shimmying alongside strippers on their off time, and leather dressed bikers all squeezed in tight together in front of the postage stamp sized bandstand. The place offers some amazing musical talent for a nominal door charge. On any weekend night you can see Barry "The Fish Melton, Nick Gravenites, Ron Hacker, Tony Perez, and Tommy Castro playing this hallowed blues joint. The place reeks of old school San Francisco and the fantastic musicians who used to play at The Saloon regularly. such as the late John Cipollina from Quicksilver Messenger Service and Johnny Nitro who passed away recently in his apt just above the joint. Nitro was a fixture there every weekend for over 20 years. Say what you want about the place but it's REAL. and it just doesn't get any better on a weekend night in North Beach.

T8AcaLi2dcDTCvPtFgxKxg.review_text: Is it really a hole in the wall if it's located in one of the city's most popular streets for bar crawling? At any rate, it's nothing fancy, even if it is also one of the city's most popular bars on the weekends. It's not intimidating, everyone's just here to have a good time. All kinds of crowds stop in here at least once - either for the rest of the night or else moving on to the next spot (for the younger crowds, that is usually the Savoy).  The fun part is the band, which usually plays on the weekends. Don't expect any songs that are too recent - just good ol' tunes that keep the crowds happy and dancing. I've gone in with friends and have had a fun time here.

kcSqnDiNjpxHc4b4T-K6Wg.review_text: This bar immediately become one of my favorites in S.F. after visiting it for the first time last night ...  The fact that this is the oldest bar in S.F. dating back to 1861 is a reason to check the place out ... the stiff drinks at half the price of many other S.F. bars is a reason to order a drink (plus, you can step up the size of a cocktail to a beer glass for 50 cents!) ... the great Blues music is a reason to hang for a minute ... and the oh-so-many characters in this place offer many reasons to stay.  From the bearded quiet guy at the door I thought might be Santa hiding out after Christmas, to the drunk bartender (the other one was sober and working double-time to compensate), to the patrons doing bar tricks, to the band nearly breaking up between songs, to THAT guy on the dance floor, to the guy who must have thought he was a professional filmmaker packing a small digital camera, I couldn't stop smiling as character after character rolled into this place.  The men's bathroom is a bit of a dungeon and I noticed a slight funk when I first walked in, but all of this is what makes this place a one-of-a-kind and truly one of the best bars in the city.

6v7kbVe-1E7qoouxPMhnQQ.review_text: I'm here on a business trip and one of my friends highly recommend this bar.  He said I would love it.  Boy was he right.  It's awesome.  We happened upon it when I was at an awful restaurant across the street.  I was pretty excited that it was there.  We went there after dinner.  It was awesome.  We ordered 4 drinks and the bill was $9.  The bartender told us that the price would go up in half an hour.  I asked to what and was told 50 cents a drink.  They had a great blues band and it was just cool.  We even bought shirts.  We're total tourists.

EjTY2XV-vlgz3428S_vpGQ.review_text: I'm giving this four stars because it's the oldest bar in the city. If a band is not playing then you don't have to pay a cover (which I didn't know and some guy was sitting on the bouncer seat smoking a cigarette and I thought he was collecting money so I gave him a $20 to pay for the four of us and walked in the bar, luckily he was a nice guy and came into the bar when he got done smoking his cigarette and gave me my twenty back). There is not a big beer selection, I think Bud Light is on tap and then you can get Heineken in bottles and about six other beers in bottles. It's a good place to go have a beer and then jet onto another bar. It's a small, small bar but I hear the music is good. Before the band started a guy came by and asked for $5 if we were staying for the band but my husband and our two friends who were in town didn't really want to stay for the band so we left.   Overall, I think you should go there once and have a drink since it's the oldest bar in the city.

rBheMfC928gnYTltxReo7w.review_text: Definitely agree with Steven G's review. It was rocking when we went in last night. Very eclectic friendly crowd  having a great time to some seriously good music. Can't go wrong with $3.50 G&T and a $4.50 beer. Don't imbibe too much as the steps to the men's room could become a problem.

6dhTfIDSmFUOUCW27Sd3gw.review_text: This is the epitome of a dive bar.  It's dark and dingy and a haven for the down-and-outers.  On any given day, at any given time, you will find at least one incredibly intoxicated patron and a handful of others who are well on their way.  It claims to be the oldest bar in San Francisco, and it looks it. Paint is peeling off the walls and the pastoral paintings are so blackened by smoke (when you used to be able to smoke in bars) that you wouldn't even know they were there unless pointed out to you by the bartender, who somehow looks 40 and 90 at the same time.  That being said, it hosts great blues acts and there is never a cover.  I would give it five stars because it's everything a dive bar is supposed to be; however, as I was sitting at the bar talking to a friend about how great the place was, a cockroach scurried across the bar in front of me, onto my bar napkin, tried to climb up my beer bottle, got bored, and then visited my friend's beer.  This was right after I ate some salami offered to me by the bartender. (Don't ask.)  I was so disgusted I had to leave.  I'm all for dingy places, but I draw the line at roaches.  I'm thankful I ordered a beer in a bottle.

JUuooHIj_ywGz7zU8Z9Ncg.review_text: Super Cheap, Great Music, Good Location, and Friendly Service.   Rockabilly Mondays are definitely worth checking out.  Unlike many rockabilly shows in SF, this one actually draws a slightly younger crowed (many in their mid twenties) and the place is often packed.  The live music is good, tips-only, and goes all night.  I highly recommend it.   I've been to this bar on other themed nights, and though it wasn't my music taste per se, I still had a great time.  The crowed is always friendly and diverse.  Additionally, you simply can't beat the prices! Drinks are good and inexpensive. Win-Win.

TMWgq3KNRDaESXs8ZCrRtA.review_text: I came in here very briefly awhile back and I think it was empty except for some homeless people.    I came back on a Wed night when there was an amazing blues band and the place was pretty crowded.  Apparently they have bands playing all the time and most of them are blues-y.  We danced and drank cheap beers.  Not much more you can ask for.  Quite an eclectic crowd.  I can't really describe it actually.  You have to go to see it.  I loved this place though and I will definitely come back with friends who will appreciate its charm.

gUMZ0P-h-pVVdVBun54sMA.review_text: all i can say is that i will be coming back for more.   nothing like crazy old people w/ some foreigners to throw in the mix. i had a great almost can't remember time here. if you like a down and dirty bar this is the place for you.  the crowds are mixed. the pissed of ol' hags and people watchers at the front and the good ol' dancin fools in the back. nothing like some dirty south blues to get a girl dancin.

oW2bCSJ5bIHyRnoZvkHwDg.review_text: Minus one star for the $5 cover.  Plus one star for me being stupid.  Stupid as I didn't listen to my friend and come here sooner.  He plays Harmonica/Harp from time to time at this place, and I was supposed to call him if I was ever in the neighborhood.  I have had a drink in a drunken stupour once or twice, and passed it on Santacon, on my way to Alice Russell at Mojito, etc.  But never really took stock.  This place is one of the most real, classic, and groovy "character" spots in the city.  It is simply this:  a blues bar.  The guy playing was just incredible, the place was smelly, the bathroom was TRIPPY and awkward for such a tall gent as me, and you can't even get to it with a dancefloor of tired, lost drunken tourists, marina boys far from home, an errant hipster or goth waiting to meet a friend, and then a whole mess of grizzled pirates that look like a cross between leather and a horse, and that is both men and women.  The barker himself with his derby, cigar, and vaudevillian charm was enough to coax me in.  The barkeep that serviced us is why this place gets five stars.  This Iggy Pop look alike was grinding out his ass on the line, vacuous to guest requests just listening to the blues and R&B echoing from the hollow body Gibson.  His robotic, autopilot arms seemed to be fierce and fragile trembling twigs that were in a frenzy to keep pace with his body that was detached from his meager, kind yet distant smile.    So I order a jack and coke with a beer.  Beer check.  Not paying attention to what he is doing.. check.  Then, the most amazing thing happens.  He is watching the band, while reaching behind him for the jack.  He is bobbing along in another world as he grabs the Cuervo.  Anyone who has worked a bar know that a bottle of Jack and a bottle of Cuervo don't look the same, but for all intensive purposes they are similar.  Not like Galliano and Jaeger sitting next to one another.  Whatever the case, without skipping a 1/4 second beat, his rote, automatist hand expresses the realization that he is into the wrong bottle, switches without a pause, flips it lazily, calmly, and without any Cocktail shenanigan flourish... pours my beverage.  This all happened in less than a second.  But a seasoned barkeep can make a mistake... but to make it, realize it, and solve it in less than a second WITHOUT PAYING EVEN A MODICUM OF ATTENTION....  ...that barkeep is your friend.    Incredible place, some of the best blues I have ever heard, let alone in this city.    Yay!

GtQuA0QRg3NPWul5XF6b3w.review_text: Wow, I have not seen so many "LOCAL" freeky north beach old-school peeps in one place since "Nam." But im not complaining, it is all part of the ambiance. This place has STANK, with a capitol "S".  I would not advise going alone; this is best tackled with a large group and not for longer than 20 mins... in case any ladies need to hit the bathroom, (better try next door).  And don't look anyone in the eye for too long, they will talk to you, it may not make sense, and it may not stop any time soon. lol

RQR-bncvVssevK_WIPWvCA.review_text: Like the Tin How Temple in Chinatown (which we visited the same day as The Saloon) visiting this bar was like visiting another world. Super old school history and style plus unpretentious surroundings and an absolutely wailing blues band were somehow exactly what we were looking for, even though we didn't think we were looking for anything.  If you love absorbing the scene vs making the scene, check out the Saloon!

N7r5J3RiaxfEPqP17LTPEA.review_text: The Saloon was SO MUCH FUN, with a live band Friday night. The drinks were cheap and delicious and the bartenders look like they've been there since the 70's.   One drawback is that it smells a little bit like a restroom inside the bar. Not sure if that is a constant or one night (due to one smelly customer) characteristic.

vn8nPLA7J_GkHEiW5vEmbA.review_text: I'm not sure what I was thinking when I suggested we go here.  Certainly not Yoko roughing up the microphone the way she did.  The second time we went was after the BF's lovely little birthday dinner with his mum, his mum's BF and little ole me.  I forget how everything in North Beach is actually just a couple blocks away from each other, but what a dense couple of blocks it is.  Like that flourless chocolate torte I'm no longer allowed to think about.  The second time was good.  I don't remember the band name but they were from out of town.  It was real decent.   I made the boys try frente for the first time, with a ginger ale chaser.  And now they both think I'm trying to poison them.  Who knew?  CASH ONLY.  Hate that.

2cIdR5891_TF9nEqQw-I-w.review_text: I can't wait to come back here...  what a joint!    scallywaggin'  barkeep, stiff, cheap drinks, loud ass fantastic live blues music, interesting crowd, endorphin and vodka fueled dance party- in short, a fantastic time!

o3vwmjnav458K41rCVgV3w.review_text: I've have been to many blues venues all over the country and this is one of a kind. Let's get this straight - it's a dive. But if you've ever heard the great Ron Hacker, Danny Castro, Steve Freund, or the many other great players ripping it up, and if you love the blues, cheap stiff drinks; then this is your place.   Some of the below reviews are just ridiculous. People, I implore you - try to have an idea of where you are and where you are going before you judge something. You will run into children at Disneyland, sick people in hospitals, dwarfs at circuses...and yes - you will find drunk people and really bad odors at divey, blues bars.
