Anywho, Had a pretty rocking blues band! we came in with a full group of people, left fairly quickly since the three older women who looked like regulars bumped us alllllll  (like literally 20 people) the way out of the only open area to stand. i don't like all their bossy signs though (such as one drink minimum per person, etc etc) i can tell you now that i didn't drink and i shouldnt be forced to when i have another 19 people with me all drinking. Sorry i refuse to drink and drive, sue me.  Bathrooms: avoid at all costs.

_rPTxBF0GPuLeMjtstDZNw.review_text: This one falls into the category of, "Know what kind of place you're going to before you get there", oh, and also, "How well does the place fulfill it's purpose."  5 Stars for The Saloon?  Really?  That dive?  Absolutely!  Picture the scene- in S.F for just a couple of nights, one of which happens to be a Sunday when the Wharf rolls up the sidewalks at 8pm, and you want to do something fun.  Definitely head to The Saloon, RIGHT across the street from S.F. icon The Stinking Rose.  Rustic, actually looks and smells like an old west broken down saloon, but filled with happy albeit mangy characters of all socioeconomic persuasions all grooving to the lively bluesy-rock-funky band stuffed in the corner.  Who cares if the lone tooth-challenged bartender takes forever to serve your drink?  And what you gotta respect so much about the place is here we are in high falutin' S.F., all they have is one beer on tap, and guess what that is - yep, PBR baby, Pabst Blue Ribbon!  And when the husky voiced singer-saxophone player jumps on the bar for a nice sax rif, the deal is sealed.  5 Stars?  You betcha!!!

voPSqQt8onshigzHdUce1w.review_text: this is a great place to get away. live music everynight. great places to eat all around the area. good times are to be had at The Saloon!!!

mcEm0-yOutL4MeRJEao7ww.review_text: The first thing I noticed on my virginal visit to this dilapidated establishment was an old homeless guy standing out front. He appeared to be asking people for handouts on their way in. I was trying to kind of sidle past him when he reached out and grabbed my shoulder, which I thought was a little rude. But then he asked to see my ID and I realized he was the doorman.   So I go in there with my friend, a blonde from the south, who I can tell is a bit reluctant. She's just started poring over the extensive wine list (the choices are "red" and "white") when this grizzled old geezer of a bartender ambles up to her and growls: "You wanna sit on my face?"   We found out later that "sit on my face" is the name of a specialty shot they were serving that night, but that's sort of beside the point. The point is that the night only got better from there. The only beer on tap was Busch, which I was unaware still existed. The clientele tended toward the old, the ugly and the alcoholic, but not exclusively so. The music was lowdown, nasty-ass blues, the wooden dance floor was cramped and grimy, there was a fake christmas tree in one corner and a prostitute in another... It was basically everything you could ask for in a bar. I've returned many times since.  Highly recommended.

qmXKvtJe83rMLXsvkRMlBQ.review_text: The Saloon is a must for locals and visitors alike. You'll get a taste of the city life and experience just a bit of the history of San Francisco when you visit.  Per other Yelpers, this is the apparently the oldest bar San Francisco. It was saved from a neighborhood fire by neighbors constructing a bucket brigade to put out the flames. Today, it's a packed like sardines, cash-only, hole-in-the-wall jazz and blues club. I happened in on the same night as the SantaCon so the place was surreally packed with people in Santa outfits in various states of inebriation. It just added to the anything goes, low key ambiance of the patrons and bar tenders in this dive bar. My vodka sodas were served in small glasses- maybe 6oz in size. These are the kind that I remember from my few visits to a VA Hall with my grandpa. It was probably for the best that they were small in size because they were big in alcohol.  Despite that cool history and fun vibe- I'm not going to lie- this place smells. For my entire visit I couldn't stop thinking I was an antique store; that musty, moth ball smell was even on my clothes when I left. Aroma aside, my visit to The Saloon this past Saturday night was a ton of fun and I would recommend a trip to everyone

PeLGa5vUR8_mcsn-fn42Jg.review_text: Less than impressed this time around - As a general rule I don't pay covers and I wasn't about to pay $5 just to pop in for a quick drink. Lots of "seedy" characters hanging around outside.  I suggest they let folks tip the band if they are worth a shit.
